just hand it over to Anand, and then we'll get to your

>> Thank you. Thank you Pax. Thank you everybody
for joining us today.

We're going to spend
the next 30 to 40 minutes talking about one of the most common mistakes

that I see in product management. It's really under this
theme of how to build

what your customers want and
what your customers need. Park shared a little bit

notes before we dive in.

I've been working in
product management in Silicon Valley for
coming up on 15 years.

I did my undergrad and my
graduate degrees at Stanford, ended up as a product
manager at Zynga and running

product management for the Words With Friends Franchise
for a few years, moved to another
startup called Dropbox,

was there for almost three years running a business product, moved to another
company called Gusto,
another company called Pilot, and I've moved my way from a product manager to a VP of product over the past ten years.

I both manage product
management teams as an executive as well as the
individual contributor.

The reason that we're
doing this webinar today is we want to take some
of the common mistakes,

common skills that we teach
to our product managers, that we hire and
teaching to everyone.

There is no magic in
product management, is a practicable skill
and a teachable skill. The goal of today is to help
give you some information

around the most common mistakes that we see in
product management. Let me start off
with what I think is

a very common thing to see if someone of product
management disciplined. You are talking to a customer,

you're talking to
someone in the audience and you get a request, someone comes up
to you says, "Hey,

it would be really great if this existed. What if we did x? What if we did y within
the cool existing system."

You go and you do it, you spend six months or a year, and hundreds of thousands
of billions of dollars to develop something
and it doesn't work.

You push this product out to your audience, it
has mixed results, it doesn't achieve the
goals that you want,

and you just back to square
1 where you started. This is by far the
most common mistakes that we see in
product management.

The reason that it
doesn't work is getting some really important parts
of process backwards.

I'll explain some core
concepts in a minute. But the fundamental mistake
that's happening in

a situation like this is when a customer comes
to you and says, "Hey, wouldn't it be great if you could build this thing?"

You're delegating
product management to your customer if you can just build exactly what they want. It's bad because you usually
end up in one of few places.

One possible places is
you have a product that doesn't actually solve
a problem for anyone. It's solves a problem
for someone but what

can't sustain the products
is a second problem. But more often it misses
together a number of different problems and doesn't

try and do anything
in particular. I mention this over and over, but this is by a very wide margin

the most common mistakes that we see in
product management. I would say that more
than half of the products

that I've worked on in my career that ultimately
were not successful, had some form of this
situation diagnosis.

Today what I'd like
to introduce is a framework that you can use to first notice when you're
in the situation,

and second, fix when
you're in the situation. To do that, I want to introduce the core concepts
for today which is

this notion of something called a problem space and something
called the solution space. These are two the cure concepts

that we teach in our classes. Stanford as well as
the online class. Let me start off by
defining the two of them,

talking about the
differences between them. Now we can talk about
how you could use them to solve the
problem that I teach.

Let's start off by defining
the problem space. What do we mean when
we say problem space? When we talk about
a problem space

in product management parlance, a problem space is the
area where you are talking about the problem you are
solving for the customer,

who your customer is, and why it's important to
them and nothing else. There's no discussion of

how you're going to
solve the problem. You are entirely focused only on understanding your customer and

the world and their
problems today, and no energy is going
into changing it at all. You're not proposing solutions,

you're not drawing wire frames, you're not drawing pictures,
you're only listening. This is a really
difficult thing to do.

It runs counter to most
people's intuitive notion. We're having a conversation with the customer and
the customer says,

I have these problems, it's very natural to want to pitch them well,
what if we did this? What if we did this?

Resist those urges
and don't do it? The goal of the problem
space is again, only to understand things that
matter to your customers,

and not to try and present
any solutions to them at all. The best way to do this is
with a set of skills that we

call customer development
or customer research. This is again its own
separate and dedicated field.

If you're in a
larger organization, or have some
dedicated researchers who can help you with this.

It is a craft that can take many years to perfect but it's another thing that we teach in both the online class and
in our class at Stanford.

It's again a practicable skill. If you've interviewed
dozens or hundreds of people and you will get better

at doing this disambiguation
almost for free. There's some common tips and
tricks they'll walk through.

The real important principle
here is you're not trying to convince your
customer of anything.

You're not trying to
sell them something, you're not trying to
pitch them something, your only job is to listen.

Again, that's a very
hard skill to develop. I also want to disambiguate
what we mean by a problem.

When we say problem,
what do we mean? A problem is just any unmet need,

want, or desire from a customer. It can be a problem
that is for feel, it can be a problem
that is experienced.

All you're trying to
do here is figure out an unmet need from
a customer perspective.

Let's do a quick recap just where we are and what
we're talking about.

We introduced this
really core concept of a problem space
and a solution space.

One of the most common
mistakes that I see in product management is
mixing up these two things, is talking to a
customer or talking to

somebody inside your
company and being unclear in your own mind whether you are trying to figure
out what their problem is,

or whether you're trying
to pitch them a solution. The number 1 tip that we have for new product managers is to be

very clear about which
mode you're upgrading. Am I in a mode where my job is to understand customers and
judge what they care about,

or I'm in a mode
where my job is to pitch a solution or a
product to customers. Again, when we say problem here,

when we say solving
a customer problem is a very broad definition
of what we mean. A problem is just an unmet need,

desire, or want
from your customer. It doesn't need to be something
that's life changing, it could be something
that is entertainment,

it could be be
something that is small but just in the biggest sense, you're trying to solve an

unmet needs for
customer perspectives. The other thing I want
to mention that problems can very much be
real or perceived.
There have been a number of occasions throughout my career where a customer expresses

a problem and it
turns out there's actually a solution
to that problem. They might just not
be aware of it, or it might be

an internal problem versus
an external problem. One of the other common
mistakes we see in product management is telling

your customers your
problem is not real. If it is real to the customer, it is in fact a real problem.

The way this gets interpreted
can sometimes be confusing.

If people are familiar
with this quote, which may or may not have
been said by Henry Ford, "If I asked people
what they wanted,

they would have said
faster horses." This is a quote that
gets misunderstood. I think it gets interpreted as

don't listen to your customers. There's a little bit of a
myth in Silicon Valley and

the phrase that "Your customers don't know
what they want, and your job as a visionary
or as a product leader is

to ignore what your customers tell you and give them
what they actually want." I think that's a fallacy. I think the misunderstanding
is actually just coming

from a subtle misinterpretation
of this quote. When a customer
says faster horses,

your job is to communicates
that what they're looking for is to get between point
A and point B in less time.

The skill of product management is to listen to
your customers and interpret their words
into a problem statement,

because a customer is always capable of articulating
exactly what they want. Definitely don't
ignore your customers

and make sure that you
talk to your customers. But at the same time
you can't just delegate

product management to them and do exactly what they're saying. Your job is to do interpretation between their words and
their actual needs.

>> We introduced this
notion of a problem space. Let me introduce the
contradictory notion

of a solution space. Problem space again,
you're only trying to understand the world
of your customers,

whether it's real or perceived. The solution space
is what probably most people think of when I think classically of
product management.

This is where you try
and change something. You build something, you prototype something,
you design something, you're attempting
to make an attempt

to solve the customer's
problem in the first place. This is for the
classic thing that people think of when they
think of product management,

wireframes, mocks,
designs, that work. But the key distinction again, and the point that we want
to highlight today is,

you shouldn't ever
mix these two things. You should be very clear on
your own mind whether you're operating in a problem space

or operating in a solution space, and don't make mix
the two of them up. Solution space very simply put is

how you're going to solve
the problem for a customer. A prerequisite for
the solution space

is understanding
the problem space. This is, again, a
very classic mistake that we see where someone

will come up with the design and they will go and
pitch it to a customer, and they won't have
a clear articulation

of what problem they're solving, so the design solves a little bit of a lot
of different problems.

It might solve 20
percent of problem 1 and 20 percent of problems 2, but when you really
look at it from

a customer perspective, there is no overarching synthesis of problems that it
solves effectively, so the customer isn't
interested in using it.

I think a good problem space
definition is basically always a prerequisite for
getting to the solution space.

So if you're working
through this in real life, I would very much
encourage you to start in the problem space before
moving to the solution space.

This is the place where you very classically think of
building something. Your job here is to build a real product or
wireframe or prototype.

I introduced a couple
of key concepts so far. One is this notion
of a problem space.

The other is this notion
of the solution space. But there are many other reasons that the product did not work.

It's totally possible to have a real problem from a customer perspective
and a great solution,

and still have your product
or your organization fail. The second thing that we
want to spend a few minutes

talking about today
is your job as a product manager is to
figure out how you can

actually capture value from
something that you've built. The really simple way
of distilling this is,

you can build something that
your customers still love that solves a real problems
for them and still fail.

I'll take one example
from recent history, but there are many more examples. I'm not sure if people
in the audience are

generally familiar
with MoviePass, but MoviePass was a company that existed up until a few years ago that for $10 per month in the US,

would allow you to watch unlimited movies for
free in theaters. Customers loved it.
There were millions of

subscribers that signed
up in the first year. From a customer need perspective, it was very clear
that they were doing

something that customers wanted. The problem for MoviePass came on the economic side of things. It turns out that when
it costs $10 to see

a single movie and you're selling unlimited movies for $10 month, the economics make it very difficult to have a
profitable company.

Just not to pick on
MoviePass in particular, but the thing that I
want to highlight is, your job as a product
manager is not

only to figure out what your
customers actually want, just to look at the
intersection of customer needs and
business opportunity.

You'll sometimes
hear this phrase, product management is for
the CEO of a product, or product managers
represent the business deed.

Your job is to bridge these
two things and make sure that you are both doing something that your customers care about,

and something that is
economically sustainable. The key insight here
is that if you go

talk to a customer and you get a customer problem from them, that does not mean
that that problem is always worth solving.

It could mean that the market is too small for your goals. It could mean that they
care about the problem,

but they're willing
to pay for it. There's a whole separate track that you need to think about as a product manager independent
of a customer problem is,

is there enough economic value here that this thing
is worth solving? I mentioned economic value.

I think it's important both in the context for
profit organizations, but also for the context of

non-profit organizations
or NGOs, etc. You need to know what
your goals are and figure out whether this thing
is actually sustainable.

What's the difference between a problem and an opportunity? This is just terminology
that we teach

new product managers when they try and change
these organizations. In my organization,
very simply put,

an opportunity is an idea
that has validated to be good for both the customer
and for the company.

It means you've done homework on two sides of the problem. It means you've spent
enough time talking to customers that you have

a deep understanding
of the problem space, and you've spent enough time
on both the strategy and the economics that you're

convinced that this
is a good thing to build for the organization
that you represent. Just a quick recap.

The second very common way that products can fail is you do build something
that customers want,

but you're not able to capture enough economic
value out of it for your company to be
self-sustaining.

We teach a handful of different frameworks

introduce today was just very simply the core
concept that your job

as a product manager is
to make sure you are at the intersection of things that are good for the user
and good for the company,

and to make sure you're not
going too far in either way. You don't want to be too selfish from the company perspective, or too altruistic where
it's not sustainable.

Again, not all problems
can actually be solved in a way that necessarily

What are the best
ways to do that? >> Totally. I think it's
dependent on two things.

One of them is whether you have an existing product and
existing customers, the second is whether you're starting something from scratch.

Let me address each of those because you can get

existing organization

or an existing product, some of the work

hopefully you already have some idea of who

the very common ways that you

You have to fix something in this equation in order to

that you can fix,
you can either fix your customers or your market or your goals. If you're starting a new company,

you have a very much
chicken and egg problem. You don't have a customer yet, you don't have a product yet, you might have a goal
and you need to figure

out which of these
things you want to fix. My suggestion for how to
work through this is to fix the goal first and
then the customer second,

because the goals really matter. By goals, I mean, what
is your definition of success for your
organization. Two examples.

If your goal, for example, is to start a company that
is worth $10 billion, there are many more
constraints on things like

the market size than
there are if your goal is to start a company that's
worth one million dollars.

That will disqualify some ideas that might otherwise
be good ideas. From a customer perspective,

again, this is a bit
chicken and egg, but my advice to people is to fix the customer and then to
find the problem for them.

It's a little bit like
fixing the market, and then exploring that market to figure out where there
might be an opportunity.

This is not the only
way to do this. You can do it in the
opposite direction as well. But to your question,
you need to fix something in order to figure out who you can actually talk to to determine whether something is a problem.

My advice for new companies
or for new organizations is, first think about your
goal slash the market,

and then think about
your customers. In an existing organization, hopefully much of this

But if you're a product manager, should you be conducting

the problem to solve and then get someone else to

the general division of labor
in terms of these things? I am sure there are many models, so if you could talk through some

Because as organizations
get larger, they end up with specialization and different
dedicated functions. So if you work in a
very large company
like Google, for example, you will have dedicated user researchers who might

be the people who
talk to customers. You'll have designated
product marketers who do a different slice of
the product management work.

So at very large organizations, there tends to be
more specialization and a subdivision of labor
between these problems.

If you're working in
an organization of, call that less than
100 or 200 people, then probably the product manager

is the person doing all of this, and your job is supposed to talk to customers and synthesize relationship and to
write the report

answering the economic analysis, so it's very much dependent
on the size of organization. The way that I prefer
to segment it in

my organizations is to try and have as much information
with one person as possible. The problem with
specialization is,

if it takes 15 people to figure
out what somebody wants, you can end up with the either designed by committee,

or one person doing a set of things and somebody else not liking the different
set of things,

so I think it's very
important to have as much information in one
person's brain as possible, so I prefer to keep the team
smaller rather than larger.

>> That's great. As you surface, so if you've got a
problem to solve,

you begin to interview customers, how do you validate
the solution space? There's the risk of, say a
biased group of customers.

Maybe you've only
interviewed 10-15, and there is always a risk that they're an unusual selection.

How do you validate the
solutions you're coming up with? How do you mix qualitative and
quantitative research to do that? >> Yeah, a really good question. I would definitely say that

there is no bulletproof
way of doing this. The bulletproof way
of doing this is to build something and try
and ship it to the world,

but that is expensive. So the whole idea of methodology, like an agile methodology or
lean startup methodology,

is to take the scientific
method and to try and apply them to different
parts of this problem.

One way that we did is that my organizations is to break down your solution into a set
of things that you need

to believe in order for your
solution to be successful. An example of this might be, we believe that the market
is of a certain size.

We believe that these set of customers actually
really has this need, or we believe that
people are willing to pay $500 for this product,

and we try and prove
our small slices of those things individually. Let's just pick willingness
to pay as a random example.

If your thesis are people
willing to pay for this, you have to use an infrastructure with the ability to
accept payments,

etc, and then you can put
it out there and see if people are actually
willing to pay for it. My suggestion is, there is not
a surefire way to do this.

Otherwise, everybody's
product would always be successful. But it's to write down the
list of hypotheses that you

think need to be true in
order for your thing to work, and to try and construct
clever ways to test them in isolation
from each other,

in particular, ways that are cheaper than building
the whole thing. What you're trying
to avoid is spending

many years or many millions of dollars
upfront researching something and then
having it just not work.

>> That's fantastic. That's good feedback. Hard to do, I
imagine, in practice.

Staying within this
problem solution space, we're getting a lot
of questions about other product management, and I do want to move
to those at some point,

but could you tease
out a little bit more? I think this is
always a challenge. It's teasing out the customers'
want from their needs.

As you said, it's pretty straightforward when

you should be doing." That's clearly what
the customer wants.

But in other cases, it could be a little bit more
ambiguous and difficult. What are some techniques for

really teasing out the need or the real problem underneath
the language of the user?

>> Totally. One of the
suggestions I have is to search for places that
are either wasting time,

money, or human effort. It's not a complete
set of solutions, but those are three of the most classically common things that

you can improve from
product perspective. An example might be, if
somebody comes to you and says,

"I have no problems," and you'd be surprised how
often this happens. You'd say, "Great. Where
are you spending your time?

In your eight-hour a day when you go to work,
what do you do?" What you might find out
is actually they spend

six hours entering
stuff into Excel, and they don't consider
that a waste of time, but there might be an
opportunity for a product there.

The advice I give is very
focused on products that are targeted to efficiency,

save money, save
time, sort of things. It's a little bit harder
to do on things that are consumer-oriented or
entertainment-oriented.

When I work for
gaming, for example, the way we would do this is, we would actually
create fake posters

or fake trailers for games, it didn't exist yet,
and see whether people are excited
or interested in it.

But I think the goal of the problem space-solution
space disambiguation is

to make sure that you are intellectually
honest about which of the two you are in and
know whether you are

trying to learn something
from customers, or give something to customers
at this moment in time,

and never to mix
those two things. >> Do you come back when
you have a solution?

Do you come back,
and do you pitch, or do you just
launch the product? [OVERLAPPING] What is that?

Is it just launching
it, not pitching it? >> No, absolutely,
you should go back, and this is dependent on
what your constraints are.

What is your timeline,
for example? What is your budget? What
is your company culture? There are companies
that do none of this,

like Apple, for example, doesn't really test any of their hardware in
large public areas. There are companies
that run betas

for 10 years at a time. It's a little bit dependent
on your company philosophy. But my suggestion for
this is, it is better,

as much as possible, to take it back to your customers and see if does
this actually work? That's the reason that
betas are so common,

or alphas are so common, or the early access are common. I think the general
best practice here is not to just launch something
and hope that works.

It's you listen to
some set of customers, build something, take it
back to those people, and see what is actually useful.

>> In those cases, to see
if it's actually useful, you would want to set up a certain set of metrics
that you're looking at,

or would you come back to the
focus group and interview, or is it a combination? >> It's usually a combination of

both qualitative
and quantitative, and part of this depends
on how big you can go in your beta period.

In some of the betas
that I've run, the beta might have 10,000
people, for example. If the beta has 10,000 people,

you can actually do
quantitative measurement. You can say how often
are people using this, how much time are they
spending on it, etc.

But if you're selling, let's say an enterprise
product for their total number of customers who have
is 50 customers,

your ability to run
really good analytics on a beta group of site might
be much more limited.

Again, it's a little bit
of the tools that you have available based on your
customer and your market. But I would try and pair as much

qualitative and quantitative
as possibly can, because doing so will decrease your probability of failure.

want to maybe shift, if you're comfortable

Maybe you have a

so I wonder if you

of how do you estimate risk in terms of
pursuing it different.

I know you've talked

valuable topic to discuss in the context
of prioritization.

>> Sure. Let me start with the prioritization
question and then we can talk about the
estimation question. From a prioritization
perspective,

you must have some set
of objectives that you are trying to achieve in
order to do prioritization.

Again, the most common
place where I see people fall down is they have not agreed on what
their objective or what outcome
they're looking for.

In an organization,
you might call this company goals, you
might call it vision, you might call it strategy,

but you must have pre-agreed on the set of things that matter. Otherwise, it's impossible
to do prioritization.

You cannot compare
disparate sets of things without knowing
which goal is important. At the organization that
I run, for example,

what we will do on either a three-month cadence or
a six-month cadence, is we'll sit down with
the executive team of

the company and we'll agree
on the goals that matter, and these might be
very quantitative. A particular example might

be that we want revenue
to go from A to B, or we want retention to go from B to C. But it can be qualitative.
We want amazing customer feedback on something we launched, etc.

But this is a little bit of a, you just have to agree on it and there is no
right way to do this,

determining whether revenue
is more important than retention is very much a function of your company or a lifespan,

the market you're in, whether
you're a venture fund, etc, and this is the reason that
being an executive is hard. So you have to agree on

the set of goals in
the first place. Once you agree on
the set of goals, now you have criteria
to do prioritization

against and the goal is to
have the ability to say, is it more important to do
something that's revenue moving or something that is
customer satisfaction moving?

Well, we have pre-committed
that we care more about revenue for this quarter than we care about
the other problem,

therefore, this
thing is important. So I think one really
important piece here is you must know what your goals

are before you can
do prioritization. Otherwise, you'll talk
in circles forever. Then the second one is to

try and take your projects and to group them into
buckets instead of comparing every project
to every other project. So another thing that
I see that ends up

taking up a lot of
organizational time is if your idea of prioritization is to take every possible project
you could work on,

put them in a giant spreadsheet, and compare it to every
other possible project. The problem here is
the combinatorics on

this is very large and if
you have 50 or 100 ideas, it is an impossible
thing to reason about.

So my suggestion for creating cognitive simplicity here
is basically to create this notion of themes or
buckets where you take projects

that work on similar topics
and you group them together, and you prioritize first at a bucket level and then
at a project level.

So from a bucket level, you might say the bucket of
projects talking about customer satisfaction
is more important

than the bucket of projects
talking about revenue, even if an individual
project might be higher ROI than something
in the other bucket.

Then you can talk about, well, within that bucket, these are the most important projects. What this does is it creates
cognitive simplicity

and organizational clarity. Especially as
organizations get larger, one of the most dangerous
things is people

being confused about
what actually matters. A big part of your job as a
product manager is to say, these are the things that matter,

move in this direction. So that's very much my suggestion on the prioritization side. Probably the most
common one is having

an unclear set of goals that
you actually care about, causing confusion in
the organization.

For your second question
about estimation, I think there's a couple of
different tools that I use,

like estimation from
my prioritization. There's an infinite number, a very large number of
prioritization frameworks.

I wouldn't say that any is better or more correct than
any of the others, but the two that I use
are some notion of

estimating impact and some
notion of estimating cost. They're not perfect.
But from an impact perspective, some of the tools we use

are a tool called
Fermi estimation, where basically, we do
back-of-the-envelope math to say, I think that if these set
of assumptions hold true,

the impacts to our
goals might be X. So it might be we can get 700 customers to
sign up for this,

each pay 100 bucks a month, therefore,
revenue will go up. On the cost side of things,

this is where you partner
more strongly with your collaborators
and engineering team

or a design team and saying, we have some rough idea of
what this thing looks like, how much do we think
this will cost to build?

Costs usually is
expressed in time, sometimes expressed in dollars, it depends on the field
that you're working in,

but one of my pieces
of advice here is being very aware
of over-precision.

It's very difficult to tell the difference between
a project that might take six weeks and seven
weeks, for example.

You can probably tell the difference between
a project that takes six weeks and a year. So the frameworks that
I use for most of

my project is hours, days, weeks, months, quarters, years, and only placing it
in one of those buckets,

because otherwise, you can spend a lot of time
trying to figure out, is it six months or seven

months and your
ability to predict that perfectly in advance
is probably not very good. The important thing to know is
that it's six months, not a year. >> Great. I think maybe it would
